body_html:
@peterjc123 , again thanks for your support.

Ok, I'll follow exactly your recommendations, but I have to understand precisely what you want me to do.

I created an anaconda env for pytorch, installing a specific python in it (conda create -n env_name python=3.6), taking for granted that pytorch would have used it (which is clearly not so, as per you answer).

Now, how can I tell pytorch to use that specific python? Alternatively, I can just add its directory to my path and move it in the fist position (I'm assuming you are referring to PATH, and not to PYTHONPATH).

Thanks!!

EDIT: I put the torch env directory (the one where python 3.6 interpreter resides) in my path and moved it in the first position. The error still persists. Here is my new Depwk scan.

_C.cp36-win_amd64.txt

body:
@peterjc123 , again thanks for your support. 

Ok, I'll follow exactly your recommendations, but I have to understand precisely what you want me to do.

I created an anaconda env for pytorch, installing a specific python in it (conda create -n env_name python=3.6), taking for granted that pytorch would have used it (which is clearly not so, as per you answer).

Now, how can I tell pytorch to use *that* specific python? Alternatively, I can just add its directory to my path and move it in the fist position (I'm assuming you are referring to PATH, and not to PYTHONPATH).

Thanks!!

EDIT: I put the torch env directory (the one where python 3.6 interpreter resides) in my path and moved it in the first position. The error still persists. Here is my new Depwk scan.


[_C.cp36-win_amd64.txt](https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/files/1618796/_C.cp36-win_amd64.txt)
